items.synopsis: Yet another South Australian builder has gone into voluntary administration, citing fixed price contracts as a factor behind debts of more than $1 million.

title.children: Another South Australian builder goes bust, Residence Building Group appoints voluntary administrator

image.altText: A close-up of the backs of the heads of two Aboriginal children.

items.synopsis: South Australia's Aboriginal Children's Commissioner is urging the state government to reduce the number of First Nations children entering out-of-home care, to avoid a repeat of the Stolen Generation.

title.children: SA Aboriginal children entering care predicted to reach Stolen Generation levels without change, report finds

image.altText: A greyhound in a kennel.

items.synopsis: As a former greyhound adoption worker speaks out about what she witnessed during her time in the industry, an MP releases what she described as "graphic and concerning and disturbing" photos of emaciated dogs and squalid kennels. Warning: This story contains content that may distress some readers.

title.children: Greyhound mistreatment concerns trigger release of 'concerning and disturbing' photos in parliament

title.children: Farming couple defiant after Voice to Parliament Yes signs stolen from SA property

image.altText: A sign saying Minda

items.synopsis: One of SA's largest disability service providers is fined more than $40,000 after a worker was sexually and physically assaulted by a youth in their care.

title.children: SA disability service provider fined after support worker assaulted

image.altText: Clare O'Neil speaks at a press conference inside parliament house

items.synopsis: The federal government says criminals have been allowed to exploit Australia's visa system for human trafficking and other organised crime, as it announces a boost in compliance officers and new rules for migration agents.

title.children: Government launches crackdown on 'criminals' exploiting visa system

image.altText: A tall man in a white beekeeping suit zipped up to his neck smiling and leaning on a box

items.synopsis: Ian Cass had been stung by bees plenty of times before and didn't know he was experiencing anaphylaxis the first time it happened. Now he has found a way to continue his passion without putting his health at risk.

title.children: Beekeeper Ian Cass had no idea he'd become deathly allergic to stings until he collapsed

title.children: First Nations high-schoolers blossom in unique native garden program

title.children: ANU students leave hospital as top cop defends dismissal of triple-0 call made by mental health nurse

image.altText: Older Indigenous man wearing a white shirt.

items.synopsis: While the prime minister has deflected questions about a national treaty, some Indigenous sovereign No campaigners want Australia to talk about it.

title.children: The No campaigners pushing for a treaty instead of the Voice

items.synopsis: Heavy rain in Victoria brings some relief to firefighters, but residents now face the threat of flash flooding, as emergency services respond to 300 calls for help.

title.children: Victorian towns told to evacuate due to major flooding of Gippsland river

image.altText: Queensland Premier Annastacia Palaszczuk delivers here CEDA State of the State address.

items.synopsis: Energy rebates and a $250 million fund to speed up Queensland's internet are announced in Premier Annastacia Palaszczuk's State of the State address.

title.children: Queensland premier reveals energy rebates, faster internet and the quantum 'frontier' in State of the State address

image.altText: A Kellogg's Corn Flakes and Special K box.

items.synopsis: The owner of iconic cereals Corn Flakes and Nutri-Grain, formerly known as the Kellogg Company, has split into two and rebranded as Kellanova and WK Kellogg Co — but Australian consumers are unlikely to notice the change.

title.children: Kellogg's splits into two, changes name and watches shares fall. But Aussies may not see a difference

image.altText: Margo Ngawa Neale, who has silver and brown hair, clear framed spectacles and red lipstick, poses for a photo by a body of water

items.synopsis: Do you know what Country is or what it means to care for it? Ever heard of Songlines? Margo Ngawa Neale, senior Indigenous art and history curator at the National Museum of Australia, is here to help.

title.children: 'It is not a surface thing': Why we spell Country with a capital C

image.altText: A roll cloud over the ocean

items.synopsis: Thunderstorms and heavy rain are forecast for parts of Victoria and New South Wales, dousing fires but bringing the threat of flash flooding, as a low pressure system intensifies over the eastern states.

title.children: Dangerous wind, heavy rain, flooding forecast to hit eastern states as intense storm system deepens

image.altText: A man standing in a narow hallway shields himself as flames explode out of a doorway

items.synopsis: Fire and Rescue NSW believe the blaze may have been sparked by a faulty e-bike battery, with 70 people being evacuated from the Mad Monkey hostel.

title.children: Sydney hostel erupts in flames after suspected lithium-ion battery explosion

image.altText: The Police Commissioner outside an ABC News sign

items.synopsis: WA Police are slammed for choosing not to appear before a Senate inquiry into the treatment of missing and murdered Aboriginal women and children, despite being scheduled to appear.

title.children: 'Absolute disrespect': WA Police snub Indigenous family violence Senate inquiry

image.altText: A woman looks directly at camera.

items.synopsis: Thousands of Australians opted to do their grocery shopping online during the pandemic, but plenty are yet to return to shopping in store as they try to get the most bang for their buck amid the high cost of living.

title.children: Sarah does 90 per cent of her grocery shopping online — but she's not checking out at the big supermarkets

image.altText: A bird's eye view of dozens of homes in a suburb, with a frame of one house being constructed.

items.synopsis: Australia's housing market is firmly in recovery mode as prices are on track to reach a new record high. Here's what's happening in your capital city.

title.children: Australian house prices are set to lift further as interest rates stabilise. Here's what's happening in your capital city

image.altText: Pat Conroy Henry Puna

items.synopsis: The Pacific's top diplomat says Australia's credibility in the region will be bolstered if the nation votes in favour of the Indigenous Voice to Parliament on October 14.

title.children: Yes referendum outcome could bolster Australia's standing, Pacfic diplomat says

image.altText: Passengers at Sydney Airport

items.synopsis: Experts say capacity on regional and international flights have not returned to pre-pandemic levels and are keeping airfares high.

title.children: Flight prices still remain high after COVID, but some tickets are much more expensive than others

image.altText: Four men standing outside talking.

items.synopsis: A man has been hospitalised and at least three homes have been lost as New South Wales south coast residents wait to see the damage left by a fire burning since Tuesday.

title.children: Prime Minister urges Bega community to dig deep as homes are lost on NSW south coast

image.altText: Flowers next to a tree with a police car in the background

items.synopsis: A road toll rise in parts of Australia has experts worried that we are going backwards on road safety.

title.children: There's a big misconception about mobile phones and driving, and it's putting us at risk

image.altText: A man and woman smile for the camera.

items.synopsis: Heather Wilkinson, who died after a suspected mushroom poisoning incident in Victoria, is remembered by her son as being thoughtful, faithful and full of grace at a public memorial service.

title.children: Hundreds attend memorial service for mushroom poisoning victim Heather Wilkinson

image.altText: An illustration of a person's hand placing a ballot paper into a ballot box held by someone else's outstretched hands.

items.synopsis: Follow our live blog for the latest news in the lead-up to voting in the referendum on October 14.

title.children: More than 900,000 early votes cast in Voice referendum in three days as AEC reaffirms impartiality

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: By political reporter Dana Morse The Australian Electoral Commission has reaffirmed its neutral stance on the Indigenous Voice to Parliament referendum, after No campaigner Senator Jacinta Nampijinpa Price suggested the organisation is favouring the Yes vote. On the campaign trail in the swing state of South Australia, Senator Nampijinpa Price made accusations about the actions of the electoral commission. "It does very much seem that there is more favour towards Yes side than the No side and that is very much a concern," she said. The AEC has defended itself in a statement, saying the organisation has always been, and remains neutral, and that the electoral commission is administering the referendum process in the same manner as federal elections.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Electoral commission responds to claims one side of the Voice is being favoured

children.content: By political reporter Dana Morse
The
Australian Electoral Commission
has reaffirmed its neutral stance on the
Indigenous Voice to Parliament
referendum, after No campaigner
Senator Jacinta Nampijinpa Price
suggested the organisation is favouring the Yes vote.
On the campaign trail in the swing state of South Australia,
Senator Nampijinpa Price
made accusations about the actions of the electoral commission.
"It does very much seem that there is more favour towards Yes side than the No side and that is very much a concern," she said.

The AEC has defended itself in a statement, saying the organisation has always been, and remains neutral, and that the electoral commission is administering the referendum process in the same manner as federal elections.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Today. Opposition Leader Peter Dutton continued his campaign against the voice in Western Australia. He was asked whether he was concerned the No vote would set back Australia's international reputation. "The prime minister predicted months ago this would set back reconciliation, that it would create an international reputational risk for us," Mr Dutton told reporters. "Did he stop? Did he change the wording? Did he tighten the wording? No, he did none of that. "The country should not be going to this referendum as the prime minister has proposed it."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Dutton says Australia should 'not be going' to referendum in the way it has been proposed

children.content: Today. Opposition Leader Peter Dutton continued his campaign against the voice in Western Australia.
He was asked whether he was concerned the No vote would set back Australia's international reputation.
"The prime minister predicted months ago this would set back reconciliation, that it would create an international reputational risk for us," Mr Dutton told reporters.
"Did he stop? Did he change the wording? Did he tighten the wording? No, he did none of that.
"The country should not be going to this referendum as the prime minister has proposed it."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Reporting by Isabella Higgins The Yes campaign is focusing on attracting votes from Australia's many multi-cultural communities, with a number of events planned in the coming days. "Misinformation is rife," said well known Indigenous leader and co-architect of the Uluru statement, Noel Pearson. He was campaigning in Sydney’s inner-west at the Addi Road Food Bank with 2023 Local Hero of the Year and founder of Turbans 4 Australia, Amar Singh. "We're working very hard to overcome the misinformation that the no campaign is throwing at all communities in the country, not the least the multicultural community,” Mr Pearson said. “We've done a heap of events with people in western Sydney here with English as a second language communities." During the event he briefly broke into song, using lyrics he says were written by “Aunty Dora” in his home community. "What of the first peoples unrecognised and unseen voices of wisdom silenced from the start, erased from history?" he sang, to the gathered group. Mr Pearson called on “the Italian,” “the Greeks,” “the Eastern Europeans,” and the “western Europeans,” who “built this country” and “built great lives here for your families”. “Extend the hand of opportunity to the original peoples of this country.” Mr Singh has travelled around the country promoting the Voice to Parliament to diverse communities because he believes it'll make "a better, more diverse Australia".
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Noel Pearson says misinformation is ‘rife’ in multi-cultural communities

props.alt: Noel Person stands in front of microphones wearing a shirt that says Yes.

children.content: Indigenous leader and co-architect of the Uluru statement Noel Pearson.
(ABC News: Isabella Higgins)
Reporting by Isabella Higgins
The Yes campaign is focusing on attracting votes from Australia's many
multi-cultural communities,
with a number of events planned in the coming days.
"Misinformation is rife," said well known Indigenous leader and co-architect of the Uluru statement, Noel Pearson.
He was campaigning in Sydney’s inner-west at the Addi Road Food Bank with 2023 Local Hero of the Year and founder of
Turbans 4 Australia, Amar Singh.
"We're working very hard to overcome the misinformation that the no campaign is throwing at all communities in the country, not the least the multicultural community,” Mr Pearson said.
“We've done a heap of events with people in western Sydney here with English as a second language communities."

props.alt: Amar Singh stands in front of a microphone wearing a yellow, red and black scarf.

children.content: Local Hero of the Year and founder of Turbans 4 Australia, Amar Singh.
(ABC News: Isabella Higgins)
During the event he briefly broke into song, using lyrics he says were written by “Aunty Dora” in his home community.
"What of the first peoples unrecognised and unseen voices of wisdom silenced from the start, erased from history?" he sang, to the gathered group.
Mr Pearson called on “the Italian,” “the Greeks,” “the Eastern Europeans,” and the “western Europeans,” who “built this country” and “built great lives here for your families”.
“Extend the hand of opportunity to the original peoples of this country.”
Mr Singh has travelled around the country promoting the Voice to Parliament to diverse communities because he believes it'll make "a better, more diverse Australia".

image.altText: group of indigenous men standing

items.synopsis: Since 2000, the rate of Indigenous Australians imprisoned has risen eight times that of non-Indigenous Australians. There are hopes a Voice to Parliament will help reverse that trend.

title.children: Australia has one of the highest Indigenous incarceration rates in the world. Could a Voice to Parliament change that?

image.altText: Kevin McCarthy in profile

items.synopsis: For the first time in American history, members of congress have voted to dump the speaker in the House of Representatives, with Republicans turning on each other to oust Kevin McCarthy.

title.children: Insults, drama and Republicans on the brink: Why America's conservatives just tore down their leader

image.altText: Eight women in a forest on a fashion photoshoot.

items.synopsis: The words that set the Voice referendum in motion have been used in a bold fashion statement to help tell the story of a community's needs.

title.children: Models inspired by elders' strength let fashion do the talking

subjects.title: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Art

image.altText: A woman and her son sit on a bench near a tree in the sun.

items.synopsis: Nagorno-Karabakh is trapped in the eye of a swirling geopolitical storm of duelling world powers. For decades, Russia has played a role in mediating conflict around the enclave, but Azerbaijan’s move to take back the area has exposed Moscow's waning influence.

title.children: A crisis unfolding in Putin's backyard has exposed the ripple effects of his dwindling power

image.altText: A bald man in a Hawaiian shirt standing in front of a tree.

items.synopsis: Gold Coast man Ashley Paul Griffith, 45, is facing more than 1,600 child sex offences stemming from a major Australian Federal Police (AFP) investigation.

title.children: Identity of former childcare worker charged with sexually abusing 91 children revealed under new Queensland laws

image.altText: A composite image shows headshots of Hunter Biden and Donald Trump

items.synopsis: Joe Biden's only living son becomes the first child of a sitting US president to be arraigned on felony charges, while Donald Trump faces the second day of a high-stakes fraud trial.

title.children: Joe Biden's son makes history in a Delaware court as Donald Trump gets gag order in New York

image.altText: Uluru with question marks super imposed over it, clolourful splashes around in the sky.

items.synopsis: The Voice to Parliament is proposed to be an advisory body made up of First Nations people from across the country who will be able to advise on policies that affect them — but doesn't the government already have a few of those?

title.children: How different would the Voice be from other advisory bodies?

image.altText: a group of people stand looking at the traditional canoe.

items.synopsis: Mitch Mahoney's ancestors used canoes made from tree bark to navigate the waters off Victoria's Bass Coast. Now, he has crafted a vessel using the same traditional methods.

title.children: First Nations artist helps kids connect with culture by crafting 'iconic' stringybark canoe

subjects.title: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Art
